title: 108_hr96
content: The "Social Security Preservation Act of 2003" is the short title of the Act. It involves the investment of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The Social Security Act is amended to allow investments in marketable interest-bearing obligations of the United States or obligations guaranteed by the United States. The Managing Trustee determines annual surplus for each Trust Fund to be invested in the following fiscal year. The Social Security Act is amended to allow investments in marketable interest-bearing obligations of the United States or obligations guaranteed by the United States. The annual surplus for each Trust Fund is determined by the Managing Trustee and can be invested in certificates of deposit in insured depository institutions. The Social Security Act is amended to allow investments in US government obligations. The amendments apply to annual surpluses starting from fiscal years after October 1, 2004. The Social Security Act is amended to protect the Social Security Trust Funds from the public debt limit. The Social Security Act is amended to protect the Trust Funds by preventing delays in deposits or credits and ensuring investments in public debt obligations. Officers or employees of the United States are prohibited from actions that would avoid increasing public debt obligations or disinvesting Trust Fund amounts. The Social Security Act is amended to protect the Trust Funds by preventing delays in deposits or credits and ensuring investments in public debt obligations. Disinvestment in Trust Funds invested in public debt obligations is prohibited if the purpose is to reduce outstanding public debt. During periods when benefits or expenses cannot be paid due to the public debt limit, public debt obligations in the Trust Funds can only be sold or redeemed to cover these payments. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue public debt obligations to obtain cash for payment of benefits or expenses from the Trust Fund, despite the public debt limit. Advance notice of sale or redemption must be given at least 3 days prior. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress and the Comptroller General regarding expected sales or redemptions of public debt obligations before the public debt limit is reached. The Comptroller General will review compliance and issue findings and recommendations to Congress. The term "public debt obligation" refers to any obligation subject to the public debt limit.
